headline.main: Toronto Journal; Do Doughnuts Make Canada Too Well Rounded?

docs.abstract: Canadian health experts fear growing national junk-food habit and increasing obesity are vaulting out of control, even while fitness centers and diet clinics sprout to counteract disturbing national trend; fewer than 10 percent of Canadians were obese in 1985, but more recent studies show figure has grown to more than 15 percent of population; dietary experts find troubling tripling of incidence of obesity among young Canadians over past 15 years; crisis has spawned alarming articles in news media, hopeful sign according to experts, who say that Canadians are becoming aware of new health threat; Canadians are still generally slimmer than Americans, among whom 20 percent of adults were considered obese in 2000; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As he waited in line at the corner doughnut shop, a 52-year-old University of Toronto graduate student agonized over a decision he would have to make in a matter of moments. ''I'm going to order either a muffin or a bagel, since I try to avoid doughnuts, although I realize that muffins and bagels have fat too,'' said the student, as he peered down at his ample midriff and across the counter to an assortment of creamy breakfast pastries.

docs.abstract: Health Club Trend Report says attendance at gymnasiums grew 29 percent since 1987 and number of hard-core fitness buffs increased even more raidly (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Obesity and couch-potatodom may be on the rise in this country, but so is health club attendance. Club members made it to their gyms an average of 93 days last year -- up 29 percent since 1987, and a record -- according to the Health Club Trend Report. The number of hard-core fitness buffs -- those who show up faithfully at least 100 days a year -- rose to a record 13.9 million, up 48 percent in the last five years alone. Perhaps they're trying to deal with life's many stresses, like corporate layoffs, falling stock prices and global unrest.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; In the N.F.L., Wretched Excess Is the Way to Make the Roster

docs.abstract: Selena Roberts Sports of The Times column questions health of increasingly heavier NFL players, who seem to be encouraged to bulk up; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PACKED beneath stressed jerseys, with bodies distorted like images from a fun-house mirror, N.F.L. players understand that excess pays in a league with an elastic waistband. Undersized? Eat yourself into the league. Pop supplements like Tic Tacs. Dissed by society? Welcome to the place where the plus-sized are embraced.
